contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish|graham flour}} {{nutritionalvalue | name=Gram Flour | kJ=1619 | protein=22 g | water=10 g | fat=6 g | carbs=57 g | fiber=10 g | | sugars=10g | iron_mg=4 | calcium_mg=45 |magnesium_mg=166 | phosphorus_mg=318 | potassium_mg=846 | zinc_mg=2 | vitA_ug = 2 | folate_ug=437 | selenium_ug=8 |niacin_mg=1 | sodium_mg=64 | right=1 | source_usda=1 }} '''Gram flour''' is a [[Pulse (legume)|pulse]] [[flour]] made from ground [[chickpea]]s or chana dahl. It is also known as '''chickpea flour''', '''garbanzo flour''', or '''besan''' (in [[Kannada language|Kannada]]: ಕಡ್ಲೆ ಹಿಟ್ಟು (Kadle Hittu); [[Tamil language|Tamil]]: தமிழ் - கடலை மாவு (Kadalai Maavu); {{lang-bn|বেসন}} [[Romanization of Bengali|''beshon'']]). Used in many countries, it is a staple ingredient in [[Indian cuisine|Indian]], [[Pakistani cuisine|Pakistani]] and [[Bangladeshi cuisine|Bangladeshi]] cuisines. Gram flour can be made from either raw chickpeas or roasted chickpeas. The roasted variety is more flavorful, while the raw variety has a slightly bitter taste.<ref name=Marks2010>{{cite book|last=Marks|first=Gil|title=Encyclopedia of Jewish Food|year=2010|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, N.J.|pages=121–122|isbn=0470391308}}</ref> In the form of a paste with water or [[yogurt]], it is also popular as a [[facial]] [[exfoliant]] in the [[Indian Subcontinent]].<ref>{{cite web | author= | year= | title= What is gram flour? | work= Blurtit.com | url= http://www.blurtit.com/q123457.html | accessdate=2007-09-29}}</ref> When mixed with an equal proportion of water, it can be used as an [[Vegan_cuisine#Egg_replacements|egg replacer]] in [[Veganism|vegan]] cooking.<ref>{{cite web |author=The Vegan Society |title=Egg Substitutes |work=Vegansociety.com |url=http://www.vegansociety.com/hubpage.aspx?id=677034 |accessdate=2009-12-31}}</ref> Chila (or chilla), a [[pancake]] made with gram flour [[Batter (cooking)|batter]], is a popular street and fast food in India. Gram flour contains a high proportion of [[carbohydrates]]<ref>{{cite web | author= | year= | title= Chickpea flour (besan) | work= Nutrition Data: Nutrition Facts and Calorie Counter | url= http://www.nutritiondata.com/facts-C00001-01c2194.html | accessdate=2007-09-29}}</ref> but no [[gluten]].<ref>{{cite web | author= | year= | title= Grains and Flours Glossary: Besan | format= | work= Celiac Sprue Association | url= http://www.csaceliacs.org/gluten_grains.php | accessdate=2007-09-29}}</ref> Despite this, in comparison to other flours, it has a relatively high proportion of [[protein]].<ref>{{cite web | author= | year= | title= Chickpea flour (besan) | work= Nutrition Data: Nutrition Facts and Calorie Counter | url= http://www.nutritiondata.com/facts-C00001-01c2194.html | accessdate=2007-09-29}}</ref> ==Dishes== In other parts of [[South Asia|South]] and [[Southeast Asia]] the flour is used to make the following: * [[bonda]] * [[boondi]] * [[Laddu]] * [[Kadhi]] * [[Pakora]]s * [[papadum]]s * [[bhajji|onion bhajji]]s * [[Bikaneri Bhujia]] * [[Burmese tofu]] * [[Dhokla]] * [[Mysore pak]] * ''[[jidou liangfen]]'' It is used in [[Italian cuisine]] to make [[farinata]], in [[French cuisine]] to make [[socca]] and in the cuisine of [[Cadiz]] in Southern Spain to make tortillitas de camarones. If [[parboiled]] potatoes are rolled in the flour prior to roasting they take on a golden colour and a crisp texture. ==See also== *[[Oralu kallu]], a type of grinding machine using stone to produce flour in some parts of India ==Notes== <references /> {{DEFAULTSORT:Gram Flour}} [[Category:Flour]] {{ingredient-stub}} {{India-food-stub}}
